texts.definition: Gameplay situations where players must choose between several different options and compare values against each other.
markups: <style="Definition">Gameplay situations where players must choose between several different options and compare values against each other.</style>

Many games tend to try and provide players with interesting choices. This is often in the form of having to choose between several good things, between several bad things, or whether to choose one or more things which have both good and bad consequences. All these choices force players to consider the <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> between the different alternatives or between the bad and good consequences of one choice.

Concrete examples of <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> provided in games are having to select which buildings or technologies to pursuit (in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization%20(video%20game)%20series">Civilization series</link></style>) or whether to rush opponents or build up one's own bases in games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/DoTA">DoTA</link></style> or the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Starcraft%20series">Starcraft series</link></style>.

The creation of characters in most <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> requires <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style>. In some cases, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls series</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>, this is mainly about what abilities and powers one should have based on what race and occupation one chooses. In others where players by abilities, powers, and skills for points, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Champions">Champions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, these players can choose to have more points by giving their character negative traits.

<style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> can be used to add complexity to <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> but also introduce different types of risks in for example <style="Link"><link="stealth">Stealth</link></style> challenges.

The construction of <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> follow one of two formats. The first is having to select between several choices which all have positive but different consequences (or all negative and different). The second is having to choose if one wants to take an action with both a negative and a positive consequence, or alternatively having to choose between several different choices with such pairs of consequences. This means that <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> are based on selecting negative or positive consequences, or both. <style="Link"><link="committed-goals">Committed Goals</link></style> is another example of the second format which allows <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> to concern gameplay aspect larger than single actions. They can in themselves support <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> but do so more (in the sense that it is more likely players need to consider them in more detail) when players need to choose from several <style="Link"><link="committed-goals">Committed Goals</link></style> that are <style="Link"><link="excluding-goals">Excluding Goals</link></style> to each other.

Typical positive consequences suitable for this include gaining <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, activating <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producers">Producers</link></style>, getting <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, receiving <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style>, expanding <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>, and acquiring <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. Examples of suitable negative consequences include suffering <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, activating <style="Link"><link="consumers">Consumers</link></style>, experiencing <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style>, having to perform <style="Link"><link="extended-actions">Extended Actions</link></style>, risk <style="Link"><link="interruptibility">Interruptibility</link></style>, losing <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, reducing <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>, leaving <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>, and losing <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>. As can be noted, several patterns can be used to create either negative or positive consequences. Some pairs of negative and positive consequences are common are worth mentioning. First, <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> combined with <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style> of other abilities are <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> as is having <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> while <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>. Similarly, using limited <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style> to have <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style> requires players to make <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style>. Other examples include <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> that protect but makes one slower or <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style> that increases penetration or chances to hit but have reduced damage. Other patterns package negative and positive consequences together and thereby have self-contained <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Off</style> structures. <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cameras">Cameras</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="chargers">Chargers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="converters">Converters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="drafting-spreads">Drafting Spreads</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="no-use-bonus">No-Use Bonus</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/One-Way%20Travel">One-Way Travel</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Player-Decided%20Distribution%20of%20Rewards%20&%20Penalties">Player-Decided Distribution of Rewards & Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-management">Resource Management</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Risk/Reward">Risk/Reward</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sockets">Sockets</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="token-placement">Token Placement</link></style> are all examples of this. <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> has this less clearly but does make players choose between guarding securely and putting their attention towards other goals. Similarly, <style="Link"><link="choke-points">Choke Points</link></style> in themselves may contain consequences related to <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> but require players to make <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> if they want to risk going to them or alternatively choosing to <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style> them. <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> gives players many actions to choose from, and as long as not all can be done imply that they need to make <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style>. <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style> forces players to make <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Off</style> decisions as soon as they cannot make use of all game elements they own. More specific versions of this can be achieved by having <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style> (since one has to select whom should receive what), by having <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> that need <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> or suffer <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style> when used (since these negative effects have to be countered by positive consequences of using the <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="renewable-resources">Renewable Resources</link></style> whose production rate depends on how much of the <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> exist force players wanting to use the <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> to choose between taking much short-term or restricting themselves short-term to be able to take more <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> later.

Some patterns can affect <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> make consequences related to <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> more important; while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Producers">Producers</link></style> can be a consequence of a specific <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Off</style>, the presence and possible activation in the future can instead make the role of consequences related to <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> be less important. <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> can tilt the weights of consequences since they can become tied to goals not related to the current context of the <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Off</style>. Finally, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style> can make it more difficult to judge the actual values of the consequences of <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style>.

Games where players need to make <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> often lead to them having to engage in <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, so the pattern causes <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>. This can also can <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and since <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style> regarding the <style="CurrentLink">Trade-off</style> can help players make better choice the pattern can also support a type of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>. In that <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> require players to select something negative with something positive or choose between two different strategies, it can have a form of <style="Link"><link="balancing-effects">Balancing Effect</link></style>. A potentially negative effect of <style="CurrentLink">Trade-Offs</style> is that they can cause <style="Link"><link="analysis-paralysis">Analysis Paralysis</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based</link></style> <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. They typically don't support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cognitive%20Engrossment">Cognitive Engrossment</link></style> in themselves but can add depth to it if it already is supported in a game through adding additional choices and effects that need to be considered.
